health_effect: Essential for life. Maintains hydration, regulates body temperature, and helps flush out waste. Safe and necessary.
Good source of plant protein and isoflavones. May lower cholesterol. However, it is a common allergen (Soy) and excessive consumption is debated regarding hormonal balance in some individuals.
Rich in Lycopene, a powerful antioxidant that supports heart health and may reduce the risk of certain cancers. Generally very healthy.
Provides quick energy (calories) but lacks nutrients. Excessive intake leads to blood sugar spikes, weight gain, inflammation, and increased risk of Type 2 diabetes.
Contains sodium essential for nerve and muscle function. However, high intake (over 2300mg/day) is strongly linked to high blood pressure (hypertension) and heart disease.
Contains antioxidants like quercetin. Supports immune health and reduces inflammation. May cause digestive discomfort (gas/bloating) in people with IBS.
Rich in monounsaturated fats (Omega-9), similar to olive oil. More stable for cooking than regular sunflower oil. Generally considered heart-healthy compared to other vegetable oils high in Omega-6.
Used to control acidity and prevent milk curdling. Generally recognized as safe (GRAS). In medical doses, it treats kidney stones, but in food, it just adds sodium content.
Known for boosting the immune system and lowering blood pressure. Contains allicin which has antibacterial properties.
A gluten-free thickening agent. Safe for celiacs. High glycemic index, so it can raise blood sugar relatively quickly.
Concentrated extract of basil. Contains eugenol which combats inflammation. Generally safe and healthy in food amounts.
Enhances Umami flavor. Generally safe for most people, but some individuals report headaches, sweating, or chest pressure (MSG symptom complex) after consuming large amounts.

Prevents bacterial growth. While safe in small amounts, studies suggest it may increase hyperactivity in children when combined with artificial food colors. Can form benzene (carcinogen) if mixed with Vitamin C in drinks.
Cheap sweetener found in processed foods. Linked to higher risks of obesity, fatty liver disease, and insulin resistance compared to regular sugar due to how the liver metabolizes fructose.
Synthetic dye. Some studies link it to increased hyperactivity and attention issues in children (ADHD). Banned in some European countries but legal in the US/Morocco.

Derived from seaweed. Used to thicken dairy/alternatives. 'Degraded' carrageenan causes inflammation, and even food-grade carrageenan can trigger digestive issues or inflammation in sensitive individuals.
Low-calorie sweetener. Safe for most, but dangerous for people with Phenylketonuria (PKU). Controversial studies regarding its effects on gut bacteria and headaches, but FDA approved.
The most harmful type of fat. Increases 'bad' cholesterol (LDL) and lowers 'good' cholesterol (HDL). Strongly linked to heart disease and stroke. Many countries have banned it.
Naturally found in citrus fruits but manufactured from mold (Aspergillus niger) for industry. Generally safe, helps preservation, and can prevent kidney stones. Rare cases of mold allergy reaction.
Fiber from the guar bean. Improves texture. High doses can cause gas and bloating, but in small amounts, it may help lower cholesterol and glucose absorption.
Commonly used to prevent mold and yeast in cheese, wine, and yogurt. Generally recognized as safe (GRAS), but can cause skin irritation in some people.
Prevents mold and bacterial growth in bread and baked goods. Help extend shelf life. Generally safe, but some linked it to behavioral changes in children, though evidence is weak.
Used in cured meats to prevent botulism and provide pink color. Linked to the formation of nitrosamines (carcinogens) when cooked at high heat.
Used to prevent fats from going rancid. Classified as 'reasonably anticipated to be a human carcinogen' by the NTP. May disrupt hormone function.
Similar to BHA, used to preserve freshness in fats and oils. Some animal studies show potential for liver and kidney damage at very high doses.
Synthetic antioxidant used to extend the shelf life of oily foods. High doses in animals have been linked to DNA damage and precancerous tumors.
Used to prevent browning in dried fruits and wine. Can trigger severe allergic reactions or asthma attacks in sensitive individuals.
Used to protect fats and oils from oxidation. Often used in chewing gum and meat products. Some concern over its effect on hormones.
Similar to sodium benzoate, used in acidic foods and drinks. Can also form benzene when combined with Vitamin C.
An antioxidant related to Vitamin C. Used to accelerate curing and maintain color in meats. Generally safe.
Derived from the Stevia rebaudiana plant. 200-300 times sweeter than sugar. Does not affect blood sugar. Generally safe, but some find the aftertaste bitter.
Extracted from Luo Han Guo fruit. Contains mogrosides, which are mogroside antioxidants. Zero glycemic index. Highly stable for cooking.
A sugar alcohol that is 70% as sweet as sugar. Most of it is absorbed into the blood and excreted, reducing the risk of digestive issues compared to other sugar alcohols.
Sugar alcohol commonly used in gum. Prevents tooth decay. Highly toxic to dogs. Can cause digestive upset in large amounts.
Used in sugar-free candies and gums. Lower calories than sugar. Can have a significant laxative effect if consumed in excess.
Very similar in taste and function to sugar but with fewer calories. Has a higher glycemic index than other sugar alcohols and can cause significant bloating/gas.
Often blended with other sweeteners. 200 times sweeter than sugar. Some concerns about its long-term safety, though approved by major health bodies.
Derived from sucrose but with chlorine atoms. 600 times sweeter than sugar. Generally considered safe, but some studies suggest it may affect gut microbiome.
The oldest artificial sweetener. Once linked to bladder cancer in rats, but later cleared for human consumption. Many people dislike its metallic aftertaste.
Popular 'natural' sweetener. Has a lower glycemic index than sugar but is very high in fructose, which can strain the liver in high amounts.
Contains small amounts of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants. Better than refined sugar but still high in calories and sugar. Should not be given to infants under 1 year.
Contains manganese, zinc, and antioxidants. Still a concentrated source of sugar, but offers more nutritional value than white sugar.
Made by breaking down rice starch. Primarily maltose. High glycemic index, can cause rapid blood sugar spikes. Some concern over arsenic levels in rice products.
Produced from coconut palm sap. Contains small amounts of inulin (fiber) and minerals. Has a lower glycemic index than table sugar.
Produced by bacterial fermentation. Used to thicken and stabilize sauces and gluten-free bakes. A type of soluble fiber; can cause gas in large amounts.
Derived from red algae. A vegan alternative to gelatin. High in fiber and zero calories. Generally safe.
A fiber found in fruits like apples and citrus. Used to thicken jams and jellies. Good for digestive health and cholesterol.
Corn starch that has been physically, enzymatically, or chemically altered for stability in high heat or acid. Generally safe but highly processed.
Extracted from cassava root. Provides a chewy texture and is a common thickener in gluten-free products. High in carbs, low in nutrients.
Derived from animal protein (collagen). Used in gummies, jellies, and marshmallows. Good for joint and skin health if high quality.
Derived from soybeans. Helps fats and water stay mixed. Contains choline, an essential nutrient. Generally safe, though a concern for those with severe soy allergies.
A popular alternative to soy lecithin. Extracted without chemicals. Generally preferred by those avoiding soy or GMOs.
Fats used to blend ingredients and soften bread. May contain small amounts of trans fats, though usually not labeled as such due to low concentration.
A synthetic emulsifier used in baked goods and dairy products. Some animal studies suggest potential for gut inflammation at very high doses.
Natural gum from acacia trees. Used in candies and sodas. Functions as a prebiotic, supporting healthy gut bacteria.
Derived from carob tree seeds. Used in ice cream and cream cheese to prevent ice crystals. Generally safe and may lower cholesterol.
Extracted from brown seaweed. Used in molecular gastronomy and as a thickener. Generally safe.
Rich in monounsaturated fats and polyphenols. Reduces inflammation and supports heart health. Best used raw or at low to medium heat.
High in saturated fat, specifically Medium Chain Triglycerides (MCTs). debated health effects; may raise both LDL and HDL cholesterol.
Rich in monounsaturated fats (Oleic acid). Extremely stable at high heat. Excellent for heart health and skin.
Low in saturated fat and contains heart-healthy Omega-3s. Often refined with high heat and chemicals, leading to some health debate.
One of the most widely used vegetable oils. High in Omega-6 fatty acids, which can contribute to inflammation if not balanced with Omega-3s.
Provides a semi-solid texture to processed foods. High in saturated fat. Major environmental concerns regarding deforestation.
High in monounsaturated or polyunsaturated fats depending on the type. Light flavor and good for high-heat cooking.
Very high in Alpha-Linolenic Acid (ALA). Highly unstable; must be kept cold. Great for reducing inflammation but not for cooking.
By-product of winemaking. High in Vitamin E and Omega-6. Neutral flavor. Good for sautéing but should be used in moderation due to Omega-6 content.
Rich in sesamol and sesaminol, potent antioxidants. Common in Asian cuisine. Heart-healthy and supports blood sugar control.
Wheat flour with added nutrients like Iron and B-vitamins (Niacin, Thiamine, etc.). Missing the fiber and natural nutrients of whole grains.
Contains the bran, germ, and endosperm of the wheat kernel. High in fiber and nutrients compared to white flour.
Made from ground oats. High in beta-glucan, which helps lower cholesterol. Generally safe, but verify gluten-free if needed.
Made from ground dried corn. A staple in many cuisines. Good source of antioxidants like lutein and zeaxanthin.
Technically a seed, used as a grain. One of the few plant foods that contains all nine essential amino acids. Very healthy and gluten-free.
An ancient species of wheat. Contains more protein and minerals than modern wheat. Not gluten-free but sometimes easier to digest for some.
A chewy grain high in fiber. Excellent for blood sugar control and heart health. Contains gluten.
Made from ground chickpeas. High in protein and fiber. Gluten-free and very versatile in cooking.
Extremely nutritious legume. Rich in protein, folate, and iron. Supports heart health and weight management.
Rich in anthocyanins (the same antioxidants in berries). Excellent for digestion and blood pressure regulation.
Loaded with antioxidants. Shown to improve insulin sensitivity and lower blood sugar levels. Anti-inflammatory.
Contains gingerol. Powerful anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties. Excellent for treating nausea and muscular pain.
Main active ingredient is curcumin. Highly effective at fighting chronic inflammation. Best absorbed when eaten with black pepper.
Contains piperine, which boosts the absorption of other nutrients like curcumin by up to 2000%.
Rich in Vitamin A and capsaicin. Supports eye health and may reduce inflammation.
Contains carvacrol and thymol, which have strong antibacterial and antifungal properties. Rich in antioxidants.
Rich in Vitamins C and A. Often used to treat respiratory symptoms and support immunity.
May help improve memory and concentration. Contains rosmarinic acid, which has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects.
Derived from plant or animal sources. While 'natural', it can include hundreds of chemicals as processing aids. Generally safe, but opaque.
Man-made flavorings designed to mimic natural tastes. Generally safe in food amounts, but lacks the beneficial compounds found in real food.
Made by macerating vanilla beans in alcohol. Contains vanillin, which has antioxidant effects. Soothing aroma.
Commonly used in baking to make dough rise. Also used medically as an antacid. Adds sodium to the diet.
Used in baking powders. Provides calcium and phosphorus. Generally safe.
Used as a white food color or calcium supplement. Generally safe, but excessive intake can lead to kidney stones.
Used to fortify foods with iron. Essential for preventing anemia, but can cause digestive upset in high doses.
Used to reduce sodium content while maintaining a salty taste. Provides potassium, which many lack, but must be limited by people with kidney issues.
Used to prevent ingredients from sticking to equipment during production. Generally safe in the tiny amounts found in food.
Used in sodas to provide tartness. High intake is linked to lower bone density and kidney stones due to high phosphorus levels.
Produced during fermentation. Used to control acidity and inhibit spoilage. Generally very safe.
A healthy base for snacks. Rich in Vitamin C and fiber (pectin). Supports heart and lung health.
High in fiber and minerals like potassium and magnesium. A great whole-food alternative to refined sugar.
Rich in Vitamin C. Acts as a natural preservative and flavor enhancer. Supports skin health and digestion.
Rich in dietary nitrates, which convert to nitric oxide in the body, helping to lower blood pressure and improve athletic performance.
Concentrated source of Vitamins K, A, and C, as well as iron and calcium. Supports bone and eye health.
Contains proanthocyanidins, which help prevent UTIs. High in antioxidants.
Essential for converting food into energy and supporting the nervous system. Often added to enriched flours.
Helps the body break down carbohydrates, proteins, and fats to produce energy. Keeps skin and eyes healthy.
Essential for energy metabolism and heart, muscle, and nerve function. Critical for brain health.
Synthetic form of Folate. Crucial for DNA synthesis and preventing birth defects. Often added to grains by law in many countries.
Powerful antioxidant. Necessary for collagen production and immune function. Also acts as a natural food preservative.
Protects cells from oxidative stress. Often added to oils to prevent rancidity. Supports skin and eye health.
Necessary for calcium absorption. Essential for bone strength and immune function. Many people are deficient.
Essential for red blood cell formation and neurological function. Primarily found in animal products; often fortified in vegan foods.
Concentrated cell contents of yeast. Rich in glutamates, providing a savory taste. A common alternative to MSG.
Similar to yeast extract. Used to enhance meat-like flavors. High in glutamic acid.
Made by boiling cereals or legumes in acid. Used to enhance savory flavors. Contains MSG as a naturally occurring byproduct.
Used in combination with MSG and Disodium Guanylate to create a powerful savory effect. Derived from meat or fish (usually).
Works with MSG and Disodium Inosinate to enhance flavor. Often derived from seaweed or yeast.
A synthetic molecule that is several times stronger than natural vanillin. Used to provide a powerful vanilla scent and taste.
The most widely used food color in the world. Class IV (used in colas) contains 4-MEI, a potential carcinogen, though levels in food are strictly regulated.
Derived from the seeds of the achiote tree. Used to color cheese and butter. Generally safe, but can cause rare allergic reactions.
Used to make foods look whiter and brighter. Banned as a food additive in the EU due to concerns about nanoparticle accumulation and DNA damage.
A secretion from beaver scent glands. Rarely used today due to cost, but technically considered a 'natural flavor'. Most vanilla flavor is now synthetic or plant-based.
A resin secreted by the female lac bug. Used to give candies a shiny, hard shell. Generally safe but not vegan.
A dye made from crushed cochineal insects. Very stable color. Must be labeled due to being a significant allergen for some.
A highly processed carbohydrate used as a filler or thickener. Can cause spikes in blood sugar; has a higher glycemic index than table sugar.
A soluble fiber often extracted from chicory root. Acts as a prebiotic. Can cause digestive gas and bloating in sensitive individuals.
Proteins that speed up chemical reactions (e.g., breaking down starch into sugar in bread). Generally safe as they are used in tiny amounts.
Whey protein that has been altered. Used as a binder or protein source. Essential allergen (Milk).
The main protein in milk. Used in bars and shakes. High in amino acids but a common allergen.
Concentrated milk protein. Excellent for muscle recovery. Contains minimal lactose but still an allergen (Milk).
Salt that contains small amounts of iron oxide (giving it a pink color) and other trace minerals. Health benefits over regular salt are largely exaggerated.
Used in 'nitrate-free' meats as a natural source of nitrates. Once added to meat, it performs the same function as sodium nitrite.
High in monounsaturated fats, fiber, and Vitamin E. Good for heart health and satiety. Major allergen.
Significant source of ALA (plant-based Omega-3). Excellent for reducing inflammation and supporting brain function. Major allergen.
Technically a legume. High in protein and healthy fats. Most common life-threatening food allergen.
Lower in fat than most nuts. Rich in copper and magnesium. Often used to make vegan dairy alternatives.
Rich in lutein and zeaxanthin. Good for heart health and blood sugar management. Major allergen.
A superfood high in fiber and ALA. Absorbs 12 times its weight in water, helping with hydration and satiety.
Contain a perfect ratio of Omega-6 to Omega-3. High in plant protein and magnesium.
Excellent source of minerals. Supports prostate health and immune function.
A peppery green rich in Vitamin K and nitrates. Supports bone and cardiovascular health.
Extremely dense in Vitamins K, A, and C. High in antioxidants like quercetin. Supports detoxification.
Contains sulforaphane, which may have anti-cancer properties. High in fiber and Vitamin C.
Rich in sulfur compounds and fiber. Supports DNA repair and bone health.
High in fiber and choline, which is essential for brain development and metabolism.
High in antioxidants that protect the brain and heart. Low in calories but high in nutrients.
Rich in polyphenols and Vitamin C. Supports heart health and blood sugar control.
Extremely high in fiber. Contains ellagic acid, which has anti-inflammatory properties.
Contains actinidin, an enzyme that helps with protein digestion. Very high in Vitamin C.
Contains bromelain, an enzyme that reduces inflammation and swelling. Supports digestion.
Rich in Vitamin A and C. Supports immune function and eye health.
Contains papain, an enzyme that aids digestion. High in Vitamin C and lycopene.
Unique fruit that is high in healthy fats and low in sugar. Extremely high antioxidant content.
Long used in traditional medicine. Rich in zeaxanthin and Vitamin A.
Contains potent antioxidants that support blood flow and arterial health.
High in fiber and minerals like potassium and magnesium. A great whole-food alternative to refined sugar.
Rich in Vitamin C. Acts as a natural preservative and flavor enhancer. Supports skin health and digestion.
Rich in dietary nitrates, which convert to nitric oxide in the body, helping to lower blood pressure and improve athletic performance.
Concentrated source of Vitamins K, A, and C, as well as iron and calcium. Supports bone and eye health.
Contains proanthocyanidins, which help prevent UTIs. High in antioxidants.
Essential for converting food into energy and supporting the nervous system. Often added to enriched flours.
Helps the body break down carbohydrates, proteins, and fats to produce energy. Keeps skin and eyes healthy.
Essential for energy metabolism and heart, muscle, and nerve function. Critical for brain health.
Synthetic form of Folate. Crucial for DNA synthesis and preventing birth defects. Often added to grains by law in many countries.
Powerful antioxidant. Necessary for collagen production and immune function. Also acts as a natural food preservative.
Protects cells from oxidative stress. Often added to oils to prevent rancidity. Supports skin and eye health.
Necessary for calcium absorption. Essential for bone strength and immune function. Many people are deficient.
Essential for red blood cell formation and neurological function. Primarily found in animal products; often fortified in vegan foods.
Concentrated cell contents of yeast. Rich in glutamates, providing a savory taste. A common alternative to MSG.
Similar to yeast extract. Used to enhance meat-like flavors. High in glutamic acid.
Made by boiling cereals or legumes in acid. Used to enhance savory flavors. Contains MSG as a naturally occurring byproduct.
Used in combination with MSG and Disodium Guanylate to create a powerful savory effect. Derived from meat or fish (usually).
Works with MSG and Disodium Inosinate to enhance flavor. Often derived from seaweed or yeast.
A synthetic molecule that is several times stronger than natural vanillin. Used to provide a powerful vanilla scent and taste.
The most widely used food color in the world. Class IV (used in colas) contains 4-MEI, a potential carcinogen, though levels in food are strictly regulated.
Derived from the seeds of the achiote tree. Used to color cheese and butter. Generally safe, but can cause rare allergic reactions.
Used to make foods look whiter and brighter. Banned as a food additive in the EU due to concerns about nanoparticle accumulation and DNA damage.
A secretion from beaver scent glands. Rarely used today due to cost, but technically considered a 'natural flavor'. Most vanilla flavor is now synthetic or plant-based.
A resin secreted by the female lac bug. Used to give candies a shiny, hard shell. Generally safe but not vegan.
A dye made from crushed cochineal insects. Very stable color. Must be labeled due to being a significant allergen for some.
A highly processed carbohydrate used as a filler or thickener. Can cause spikes in blood sugar; has a higher glycemic index than table sugar.
A soluble fiber often extracted from chicory root. Acts as a prebiotic. Can cause digestive gas and bloating in sensitive individuals.
Proteins that speed up chemical reactions (e.g., breaking down starch into sugar in bread). Generally safe as they are used in tiny amounts.
Helps with digestive issues and may lower blood pressure. Often used for its aromatic flavor.
Highest antioxidant content among spices. Contains eugenol, often used in dentistry for pain relief.
Used in small amounts to aid digestion. Large doses can be toxic and hallucinogenic.
Rich in iron. Helps stimulate digestive enzymes and improve gut health.
Seeds (spice) and leaves (cilantro). Helps lower blood sugar and supports immunity.
Contains anethole, which has anti-inflammatory properties. Often used to reduce gas and bloating.
Rich in selenium and magnesium. Helps boost metabolism and reduce inflammation.
The world's most expensive spice. Shown to improve mood and symptoms of depression.
Contains compounds that help break down proteins and soothe the stomach.
Relaxes the muscles of the digestive tract. Excellent for Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) symptoms.
Used for improving brain function and treating sore throats. High in antioxidants.
A member of the mint family. Reduces stress and anxiety and helps promote sleep.
Binds to minerals to prevent them from causing odors or discoloration. Generally safe, but can deplete minerals in high amounts.
Used in baking and to keep potatoes from browning. Excessive intake may affect mineral balance.
Traditional leavening agent for crisp cookies and crackers. Generally safe.
Used to dissolve flavors in foods. Generally recognized as safe.
A synthetic fiber used to replace sugar and fat while adding bulk. Can cause bloating in high amounts.
Used to keep foods moist or as a carrier for flavors. Generally safe in food amounts, but a controversial ingredient in some countries.
Synthetically produced emulsifier used to maintain texture in cakes and whipped toppings. Generally safe.
Used to prevent ingredients from clumping together. Generally safe.
A simple sugar found in fruit. In isolated form (processed), it can contribute to fatty liver disease when consumed in excess.
A mixture of glucose and fructose. Used to keep baked goods moist. Similar health profile to table sugar.
Often used to sweeten 'no sugar added' products. Primarily sugar, though it contains some antioxidants.
A common sweetener for juices and snacks. High in fructose and calories with minimal fiber.
A by-product of sugar refining. Rich in iron, calcium, and magnesium. Healthiest among liquid sweeteners.
Contains lentinan, which supports the immune system. Rich in B vitamins and Vitamin D (if sun-dried).
Used in traditional medicine to reduce stress and improve sleep. Supports immune health.
May stimulate the production of nerve growth factor (NGF). Supports memory and focus.
Extremely high in antioxidants. Supports immune function and anti-inflammation.
Commonly used in sushi. Excellent source of iodine and trace minerals. Contains some B12 (rare for plants).
Low in calories, high in nutrients. Contains fucoxanthin, which may help with fat burning.
Extremely high in iodine, which is critical for thyroid function. High in weight-loss-supporting nutrients.
A nutrient-dense blue-green algae. High in protein, iron, and B-vitamins. Supports detoxification.
Rich in chlorophyll and protein. Known for its ability to bind to heavy metals for detoxification.
A high-quality protein from yellow peas. Rich in BCAAs. Easy to digest and gluten-free.
Often combined with pea protein for a complete amino acid profile. Gentle on the stomach.
Contains all essential amino acids. Highly nutritious and gluten-free.
Protein derived from connective tissue. Supports skin elasticity and joint health. Not a complete protein.
A complete protein that is easily absorbed. Fat-free and low-carb.
Beneficial bacteria that support digestion and immune health. Aids in the breakdown of lactose.
Helps improve digestive regularity and supports the body's immune response.
The primary source of inulin. Feeds beneficial gut bacteria. Can cause significant bloating in some.
A bulk-forming laxative. Helps lower cholesterol and improves heart and gut health.
Made from fermented alcohol. Generally safe; helps stabilize food and adds sharp flavor.
Contains 'the mother' (bacteria/enzymes) if unfiltered. Benefits include blood sugar control and weight loss.
Made from grape must. Contains polyphenols. Adds intense flavor without many calories.
Rich in savory flavor but also very high in sodium. Essential allergen (Soy, Wheat).
A variety of soy sauce made with little to no wheat. High in sodium but safe for celiacs.
Fermented soybean paste. Rich in enzymes and beneficial bacteria. High in sodium.
A fermented liquid condiment. Contains anchovies (allergen), vinegar, and spices.
Low-calorie condiment made from mustard seeds and vinegar. Contains beneficial phytonutrients.
Made from oil, egg yolk, and vinegar. High in calories. Essential allergen (Egg).
Contains tomato paste (lycopene) but is often very high in sugar and high fructose corn syrup.
Natural floral water. Generally safe and used in Middle Eastern sweets.
Extracted from orange flowers. Adds a distinct floral note. Generally safe.
Raw form of cocoa. Extremely high in antioxidants and magnesium. Supports heart health.
The fat from the cacao bean. Rich in stearic acid, which doesn't raise cholesterol as much as other saturated fats.
Rich in antioxidants that support blood flow and heart health. Lower in sugar than milk chocolate.
Naturally high in potassium and magnesium. A great natural alternative to sports drinks.
Often easier to digest than cow milk for some people. High in calcium and protein. Essential allergen (Milk).
Made from almonds and water. Naturally low in calories but often fortified with vitamins. Major allergen.
High in fiber and creamy texture. Naturally sweet. Often fortified.
Very creamy and versatile. Naturally high in healthy fats. Major allergen.
Extremely rich in beta-carotene. High in fiber and low in calories.
Excellent source of complex carbs and Vitamin A. Supports skin and immune health.
Rich in antioxidants and Vitamin A. Supports eye health.
Low calorie and hydrating. Contains antioxidants like apigenin and luteolin.
Highest nutrient density score of any vegetable. Supports bone and cardiovascular health.
Supports detoxification and gut health. Rich in fiber.
Contains more antioxidants than white onions. Supports immune and heart health.
More concentrated in antioxidants than onions. Rich in Vitamin A and B6.
Contains kaempferol, which protects blood vessel linings. Supports heart health.
Extremely high in Vitamin C. Red peppers contain the most nutrients.
Contains capsaicin, which boosts metabolism and reduces pain.
A blend of spices. Supports metabolism and immune function.
Strong metabolism booster. Helps reduce hunger and lower blood pressure.
Potent flavor. Supports digestion and can help treat headaches.
Sweeter than peppermint. Supports hormone balance and digestion.
Often used to treat digestive issues. Rich in Vitamin C and A.
Excellent for bone health and may help freshen breath.
May help the body clear heavy metals. Supports digestive health.
Supports heart health and blood sugar regulation.
Used for respiratory health and digestive support.
Used in Asian soups. Supports healthy cholesterol levels and reduces inflammation.
Contains shikimic acid, a precursor to flu medication. Strong antimicrobial properties.
Used for anxiety and sleep. Generally safe in food amounts.
Often consumed as tea. Shown to lower blood pressure and support liver health.
Contains apigenin, which binds to receptors in the brain to promote sleep.
Extremely high in catechins (EGCG). Boosts fat burning and supports brain health.
Supports heart health and gut health. Contains caffeine.
Extremely high in caffeine. Boosts focus and metabolism. Can cause jitters in high amounts.
Provides caffeine along with vitamins and minerals. Less jittery than coffee for some.
Powdered green tea. Provides a 'calm focus' due to L-theanine. Extremely high in antioxidants.
Found in tea. Promotes relaxation without drowsiness. Often paired with caffeine.
Essential for heart and brain function. Often added to energy drinks. Generally safe.
Helps the body turn fat into energy. Supports heart and brain health.
One of the most researched supplements. Supports strength, power, and brain health.
Helps buffer acid in muscles during exercise. Can cause a 'tingling' sensation.
Supports the lining of the gut and immune function. Critical during illness or stress.
A highly absorbable form of magnesium. Supports sleep and muscle function. In higher doses, acts as a laxative.
Buffered with glycine. Very gentle on the stomach. Excellent for sleep and anxiety.
Essential for immune cell function and wound healing. Common in cold remedies.
Critical for thyroid function and DNA production. Powerful antioxidant.
Essential for making red blood cells and maintaining nerve cells and the immune system.
Necessary for the production of thyroid hormones. Found in seaweed and iodized salt.
Supports bone formation and helps the body process protein and cholesterol.
May improve insulin sensitivity and enhance protein, carbohydrate, and lipid metabolism.
Essential for enzymes that break down certain amino acids and harmful substances in the body.
Directs calcium to the bones and teeth and away from the arteries. Critical for heart health.
Essential for eye health and skin. Synthetic form used for fortification.
Necessary for making blood cells and converting food into energy.
Involved in neurotransmitter synthesis and immune function.
Essential for the metabolism of fats and carbohydrates. Supports keratin production.
Protects the eyes from blue light and oxidative damage.
Works with lutein to protect the macula of the eye.
Found in tomatoes. Supports prostate health and protects skin from sun damage.
A soluble fiber found in oats and mushrooms. Lowers cholesterol and boosts immunity.
Supports bile production and liver detoxification.
Contains silymarin. Used to protect the liver from toxins and inflammation.
Helps the body manage stress. Improves sleep and may boost testosterone.
Boosts energy levels and supports immune function. May improve cognitive performance.
Supports a healthy response to stress. Anti-inflammatory and antioxidant.
An adaptogen from Peru. Supports energy, focus, and hormonal balance.
Acts as a gentle diuretic and supports liver health.
Rich in antioxidants. Often used to shorten the duration of the common cold and flu.
Popular herbal remedy for fighting infections and supporting the immune system.
Used for centuries as a natural sleep aid and anti-anxiety treatment.
Helps relieve anxiety and insomnia by increasing GABA levels in the brain.
An adaptogen that helps the body adapt to physical and mental stress. Reduces fatigue.
Concentrated form of curcumin for maximum anti-inflammatory benefits.
A flavonoid found in onions and apples. Natural antihistamine and anti-inflammatory.
Found in red grapes and wine. Activates 'longevity genes' and protects the heart.
Essential for energy production in cells. Protects the heart and brain.
Universal antioxidant that helps lower blood sugar and improve nerve function.
The most important antioxidant produced by the body. Supports detoxification and immune health.
Precursor to glutathione. Supports respiratory health and liver detoxification.
Derived from the soapbark tree. Used in root beer and sodas for foam. Generally safe.
Used for foam and flavor. Contains saponins which may have anti-inflammatory properties.
Used to prevent fat bloom in chocolate. Generally recognized as safe.
Used in some liquid eggs or marshmallows to improve texture. A common detergent also used in soap; some avoid it for potential irritation.
Used in chocolate and baked goods to prevent fat separation. Generally safe.
Used in ice cream and baked goods. Some animal studies link high amounts to gut microbiome changes.

ingredient: Propylene Glycol Esters of Fatty Acids
health_effect: Helps keep cakes light and fluffy. Generally safe.
Commonly used in cheap chocolate to reduce cocoa butter content. Generally safe but highly processed.
Used to strengthen bread dough. Generally safe as it breaks down quickly.
Used to bleach flour and strengthen dough. Banned in many countries as it's also used in plastics. Potential respiratory irritant.
Used to whiten flour. Also a common acne treatment. Generally safe in food amounts.
Used to keep citrus flavors mixed in sodas. Banned in many countries due to bromine accumulation in the body and potential health risks.
Used to prevent scale in water and maintain texture in foods. High intake of phosphates is linked to kidney issues.
Used in seafood and meat to keep them moist. Excessive phosphate intake can be harmful to kidneys and heart.
Used in instant puddings and cheese. Adds significant phosphorus to the diet.
Prevents metallic tastes and discoloration. Generally safe in small amounts.
Used in some drinks or candies. Also a stool softener. Generally safe in tiny food amounts.
Used to coat candy or prevent dust in grains. Non-absorbable by the body. Some concern over contamination.
Used to coat fruits or candies. Passes through the digestive system unchanged. Generally safe but non-nutritive.
Historically used in confections. Now replaced by vegetable waxes due to animal protection laws.
A synthetic fat that provides no calories but can cause 'anal leakage' and nutrient depletion. Rarely used today.
Made from wood pulp or cotton. Used to increase fiber content or reduce fat. Generally safe but non-nutritive.
A refined wood pulp product. Used to prevent clumping and add bulk. Generally safe.
Derived from insects. Must be specifically labeled for those with allergies. Known to cause severe anaphylaxis in rare cases.
Used to blacken olives. Also an iron supplement. Generally safe.
A carotenoid used to color salmon and egg yolks. High amounts can cause retinal damage.
Used in maraschino cherries. FDA has banned it in cosmetics due to thyroid cancer risk in rats, but it's still legal in food.
Used in candies and snacks. Potential links to hyperactivity in children.
A synthetic dye. Banned in the EU due to concerns about tumorigenicity in animal studies.
Used to strengthen dough. Also provides iodine. Generally safe.
Used in salty licorice (salmiak). Generally safe but has a strong, pungent taste.
Used in gelatin desserts to provide a sharp taste. Generally safe.
Used in tortillas and sour breads. Generally safe and helps prevent mold.
Naturally found in green apples. Provides a lingering sour taste. Generally very safe.
Used to curdle tofu and in sausages. Generally recognize as safe.
Used in beer and non-alcoholic drinks. A paraben; some concern regarding endocrine disruption.
Used in canned asparagus and beverages to maintain color. Generally safe at low levels.
Used in pickles and canned vegetables to keep them firm. Also a source of calcium.
Used to curdle soy milk into tofu. A good source of magnesium.
A relatively new preservative derived from natural amino acids. Generally safe.
A natural preservative produced by bacteria. Used on cheese and sausages to prevent mold. Generally safe.
A natural preservative produced by fermentation. Effective against a wide range of bacteria. Generally safe.
Used in beer foam and salad dressings. Generally safe.
Used in chocolate-covered cherries to liquefy the sugary center. Generally safe.
Breaks down starches into sugars. Naturally occurs in saliva; used in baking. Generally safe.
Helps soften dough by breaking down gluten. Generally safe.
Used in cheesemaking to develop flavor. Generally safe.
Added to milk to make it 'lactose-free'. Essential for those with lactose intolerance.
Used to clarify juices and process coffee. Generally safe.
Used to remove oxygen and prevent browning in dried eggs and wines. Generally safe.
